MatheTraffics

A Personalized Mathematical Model of Macroscopic Traffic Flow

Adharsh Sathyavasan Thirunavukkarasu

Aditeya Shukla

Mihir Chaturvedi

Kanad Pardeshi

Traffic and its impacts

  • Time delays
  • Unnecessary stress
  • Road rage
  • Higher fuel consumption
  • Problems in provision of emergency verhicles
∨

MatheTraffics

A Personalized Mathematical Model of Macroscopic Traffic Flow

∧
∨

Assumptions

  • Every driver takes decisions with respect to their best interests
  • Absence of random and unpredictable events
  • Synchronised and ideal traffic signals
∧
∨

Hypothesis

It is possible to use mathematical analysis to find the optimum route and minimum time delay for a route from any two points A and B taking into account traffic density, route distances and traffic signals.

∧
∨

Working Method

speed
=
distancetime
v
=
st
t
=
sv
t
α
s

As distance decreases, time also decreases

∧
∨

Traffic Density

∧
∨

Relation between average traffic density and maximum average speed:

v
=
(-2 × 10-10) x3 + (3 × 10-6) x2 - 0.061x + 51
∧
∨

Example 1 - 10AM

  • Route 1 : 1440 cars/hour
  • Route 2 : 2051.61 cars/hour
  • Route 3 : 1200 cars/hour
  • v1 : 33.58 km/h
  • v2 : 29.08 km/h
  • v3 : 35.78 km/h
  • t1 : 8.93 minutes
  • t2 : 12.79 minutes
  • t3 : 16.1 minutes
    • ∧
    ∨

    Example 1 - 12 Noon

  • Route 1 : 2736 cars/hour
  • Route 2 : 1238.71 cars/hour
  • Route 3 : 1450 cars/hour
  • v1 : 25.58 km/h
  • v2 : 35.40 km/h
  • v3 : 33.50 km/h
  • t1 : 11.73 minutes
  • t2 : 10.55 minutes
  • t3 : 17.2 minutes
    • ∧
    ∨

    The Problem

    • A road has infinite traffic signals, each spaced 1500m apart.
    • All of them turn red and green simultaneously.
    • They stay green for 90 seconds and red for 60 seconds alternately.
    • What values of v would be there so that the car can pass through the maximum number of traffic signals without facing a red light?
    ∧
    ∨

    The Solution

    ∧
    ∨
  • v1 : 33.58 km/h
  • v2 : 29.08 km/h
  • v3 : 35.78 km/h

    • Since the maximum average speed is 33.58 km/h,

    The optimum speed in this case would be 27 km/h

    ∧
    ∨
  • v1 : 25.58 km/h
  • v2 : 35.40 km/h
  • v3 : 33.50 km/h

    • Since the maximum average speed is 35.4 km/h,

    The optimum speed in this case would be 35 km/h

    ∧
    ∨

    Results

    We have gained the to analyse traffic trends in a given route and a method to choose the best route possible with respect to the related factors.

    ∧
    ∨

    Applications

    • Reduction in congestion and time delay
    • Rapid provision of emergency services
    • Applications in other congestion problems
    ∧
    ∨
